title: How to deal with a story that 95% of it takes place in a different language country and the protagonist speaks in it - Quora

response.answer_text: Q: How do I deal with a story that 95% of it takes place in a different language country and the protagonist speaks in it? Remember your narrator, and convey things in the way your narrator perceives and understands them. If the narrator understands the language, then “in [language]” might be mentioned to establish when there’s a change in what a character is speaking, but a truly multilingual person can have conversations without realizing the language they’re in, so it won’t always matter. I have one narrator in a fantasy series who visits places where she doesn’t know the language—she frankly doesn’t even know one of the two major languages of her home city. She can sometimes recognize the language that’s being used, but in general, she makes assumptions or guesses from context. Sometimes that means characters communicate by gestures rather than words. Whereas another narrator, multilingual, knows a lot of languages (some of it’s magic) and thus might sometimes take a moment to switch, but she in general navigates situations fine. (Even she, though, sometimes makes unwarranted assumptions, because I like my unreliable narrators.) You start with your narrator, then build from there.

There’s the Tolkien option: He’s translating from Bilbo’s account in Middle Earth language…and adapting whatever needs adapting. You didn’t think the hobbit spoke English, did you? In fact, Merry and Pippin aren’t named Merry and Pippin (or Meriadoc and Peregrine) but names in their language with similar meanings. If your protagonist is also your point of view, you can just say once that he understands the different language and leave it all in English anyway, maybe adding a line about not-English speaker complimenting your protagonist’s foreign language (or making fun of their accent, or correcting a mix-up - whatever works) here and there. There might be other options, but what you don’t do is having 95% of your dialogue in a different language for the reader to scratch their head at.
